bibl.title: Letter from Charles W. Comstock to R.B. Howland, March 30, 1922

div1.p: Comstock describes possible yellow fever cases to Howland. All involve foreigners in Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from Charles W. Comstock to R.B. Howland, March 30, 1922
div1.opener:
Copy
DWIGHT P. ROBINSON & COMPANY
125 East 46 Street
New York
Fortaleza, March 30, 1922.
Dwight P. Robinson & Co., Inc.,
125 East 46 Street,
New York, N.Y.
Attention Mr. Howland
Dear Mr. Howland:
div1.p:
After some consideration of your letter of February 22 on this sub-
ject, I turned over the yellow fever vaccine sent by you, together with the lit-
erature on the subject and Dr. Noguchi's letter of instructions, to Dr. Jose
Paracampos, the Chief Officer of the Inspectoria medical service. Dr. Philo-
meno, to whom the letter was addressed is Dr. Paracampos' assistant.

I have not up to this time said anything about the matter to our
men, partly because I am a little afraid of creating a panicky feeling, but
chiefly because I'm not convinced that this vaccination is generally necessary.

The number of cases here has been few, all among the foreigners it
is true, and all are traceable to two centers of infection, viz., the two prin-
cipal hotels in Fortaleza.

The first case was that of C. D. Ashmore, a man sent here by the
American Locomotive Co., who arrived May 6, 1921 and died May 31, 1921.

The second was that of E. T. Walsh, who died November 10, 1921, in
the interior but a short time after he left Fortaleza. There is no doubt but
that he was inoculated with the disease here.

The third was G. W. Naill, who had a narrow escape from death.
He had lived in close association with Walsh during the latter's illness and
no doubt contracted the disease from that association.

The fourth was Mr. Robotton's daughter, twelve years old, living at
one of the suspected hotels. She escaped death by a narrow margin.

The fifth was McGuckin who undoubtedly was inoculated during the
last few days of his stay here and became ill about two days after sailing.
There seems to be no doubt that he had yellow fever, notwithstanding the
death certificate gave another cause.

I am told by Brazilians of high standing that the Government medical
authorities never allow yellow fever to be assigned as a cause of death if
they can help it, so that they may say to the world at large “there is no
yellow fever in Brazil.” This ostrich policy delays any preventive measures
until they are forced by an epidemic.

The explanation of the fact that all the cases are among foreigners
seems to be that all the natives have had the disease as children, a large
proportion dying before they are two years of age, and the survivors having
a certain immunity.

In the interior conditions are not favorable to the spread of the
disease, as there are very few mosquitos. About Fortaleza there are many
standing pools, many of which cannot be covered with oil, as for instance all
the water supply is from shallow dug wells from which water is pumped by wind-
mills to elevated tanks. Both wells and tanks are open and are excellent
breeding places for mosquitoes. The reform of all the unsanitary conditions
here would require a dictatorship such as existed in the Panama Canal Zone.

I do not mean to convey the idea that there is any great danger of
yellow fever in Fortaleza and I think there is practically none at all in the
interior.

There are only a few of us who make headquarters in Fortaleza. We
have a house of our own which we make strenuous efforts to keep above the
native standard of cleanliness. We sleep under mosquito nets and take the pre-
caution to stay at home in the evening, at which time the mosquitoes are
especially active.

Notwithstanding my feeling that there is little or no danger from
this cause, it is a comfort to know that the preventive vaccine is available
in the event that my views should change or in case some of the others may
feel differently.

I assure you that your trouble and thoughtfulness in providing
this facility is greatly appreciated by me, as I know it would be by the
others if the fact were generally known.
